questions.question: Mob programming involves:
options: The whole team collaborating at one keyboard with explicit roles and timeboxes
Managers writing code with the team
questions.additionalContext: Mob sessions synchronize attention and decision‑making via facilitation, roles, and timers.

questions.question: Key roles often used in mobs:
options: Only Driver and no other roles
questions.additionalContext: Driver operates the keyboard, Facilitator manages flow, Navigator(s) guide approach and architecture.

questions.question: When mobs are most beneficial:
questions.additionalContext: Mobs accelerate convergence on complex, high‑impact decisions and gnarly bugs.

questions.question: An expected outcome of effective mobbing:
options: Wider knowledge spread and shared mental models
questions.additionalContext: Collective validation reduces rework, and shared mental models increase throughput later.

questions.question: Risk to watch for in mobs and mitigation:
options: Social loafing; rotate roles and keep contributions visible
Too many keyboards; add more keyboards
questions.additionalContext: Timeboxed rotations and explicit contributions help maintain engagement.

questions.question: Anti‑pattern indicating a meeting smell:
options: Defined agenda, outcomes, and breakout plan
Clear decision record (ADR) at the end
Explicit handoffs to pairs for implementation
questions.additionalContext: Without agenda and timeboxes, mobs devolve into meetings. Create outcomes and breakouts.

questions.question: Artifact that helps post‑mob alignment:
options: Architecture Decision Records (ADRs) summarizing key decisions
questions.additionalContext: Summarize key decisions and rationale into ADRs and issue descriptions for clear handoffs.

questions.question: Good follow‑up after a mob session:
options: Rotate prompts across team members to sustain engagement
Delay all actions until next quarter
questions.additionalContext: Rotate prompts and actions to keep engagement high and spread ownership.

questions.question: Design a 60‑minute mob for diagnosing a gnarly production bug. Include roles, agenda, timeboxes, and breakout triggers. How will you capture decisions?
questions.sampleStrongResponse: Agenda: 5m context, 20m hypothesis generation, 20m focused investigation, 10m decision, 5m next steps. Roles: Facilitator, Driver, 1–2 Navigators. Breakout when two viable paths emerge. Capture decisions and rationale in an ADR and issue with owners and due dates.

questions.question: You have to define cross‑cutting architecture for a new platform. Propose a mob plan and success metrics to justify the time investment.
questions.sampleStrongResponse: Plan: 90‑minute mob with rotating Driver/Navigators, explicit agenda, and timeboxed spikes; follow with ADRs and pair breakouts to implement. Success: fewer rework cycles, faster convergence on decisions, improved alignment scores, and reduced incident rate due to early validation.
